Threads.Reply_Text: The mentality that "someone else had it worse, so accept whatever you got" is something sadists and enablers use to keep us ACoNs in the dark and stunted in our healing. I remember getting this flak from members of my community growing up as well as douchebags on internet forums had this effect on me.

Replies.Reply_Text: "Get down the cancer wards and get some fucking perspective" is something I heard a lot. Then next breath "Why haven't you cleaned up the dishes??? No other child would EVER do this to their mother"

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not everyone else‚Äôs mother.‚Äù

Been there a bunch of times, but how the hell do you explain that something to someone? I had trouble explaining it to a lifelong friend and he KNEW what my mom was capable of. Hard to avoid the feeling that my PTSD is invalid because I can't nail it down to one instance or sum it up in an easily understandable sentence.

I feel like that myself too, and with my C-PTSD too. I'm... I don't wanna say lucky, but my n-mom literally kidnapped me and nearly killed my infant baby sister with neglect so I usually lead with that and add "and she got worse with age".

Sometimes just saying "my parents were abusive" is enough, because it's true, even if they never hit you.

I am emotionally fine 20 years later, but I still get hurt thinking sometimes how screwing up my legs for life and making sure I don‚Äôt feel confident about my looks was not enough that she had to always put it down with ‚Äúgo to cancer ward‚Äù or ‚Äúgo to orphanage‚Äù and see how they are living. I know it‚Äôs shitty for me to say but as a child all I thought was ‚Äúcancer could mean death and I could be free‚Äù and ‚Äúorphanage doesn‚Äôt have you‚Äù.  And honestly the thing that frustrates me the most is still being told ‚Äúshe‚Äôs your mom, the only mom you have, you can‚Äôt hate her!‚Äù Yes. Yes I can. I‚Äôm sorry for this rant, just got emotional and angry for a second lol

This is definitely the right place for an emotional rant! I sympathize with those thoughts completely- I used to plan out how to run away when I was younger, but when I got old enough to realize that wouldn't work in a town of 2,000 people that four generations of your family lives in I switched to looking up how to get emancipated, rent rates for apartments, could I survive on my waitress job and still finish high school (I could not), I even seriously talked to my uncle on my mother's side about moving in with him.

I hate my parents. Honestly and truly. It's nice to be able to say that without people screaming that I shouldn't. Usually my reply to "you can't hate them!" is "why not? they hate me. they told me that many times. why am i obligated to love someone who doesn't love me?"

(Waitress first, then McDonald‚Äôs nightshifts to try to make it to classes, ended up with a nice burnout)

"She's your mom and the only one you've got. You HAVE to forgive her. You don't want to have any regrets." It took me a long time to realise how WRONG this idea is. It doesn't matter who the person is. NO ONE has a free pass to abuse you.

You got that exactly! I have been NC for over 20 years and I still get that every now and then. No- I do NOT have to forgive anyone but myself. I am worth the time and energy it takes to keep myself from being poisoned and burnt and hit and belittled - the ONLY forgivness I need to participate in is forgiving myself for not eliminating the relationship earlier and loving myself through it all. And I forgive me for that. And when I realized THAT was my forgiveness to give- wow! My anger diminished, my life got brighter and over time more and more time passes between bouts of hating myself or backsliding.
20 years in- life is genuinely good
I have found a way to live without the anger every minute - and I have never forgiven her.
Mostly, I just dont think of her.
It gets better. I swear.
How do I guide myself to truly realize those things so I could also feel like life is brighter ?

Best advice I can give is also the most difficult: find support. People to lean on. People who believe you and believe IN you. Reach out. Find people -on here or at irl support groups.

Or a parent of a friend. If you feel like you can trust them, take a chance. Reach out to them and be honest.
